awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Microfabrication and Self-Assembly of Shape-Changing Hydrogels with Chromonic Liquid Crystalline Order
awd_abstract_narration:
Shape-changing liquid crystal hydrogels are soft, rubbery materials that can perform mechanical work as "artificial" muscles, without motors, joints, or control systems. They move spontaneously in response to slight temperature changes, and can be designed to flex in different geometries. This collaborative research effort focuses on developing techniques to engineer these materials to produce novel devices such as self-cleaning surfaces. Like the cilia that sweep contaminants from human lungs, surfaces will be coated with micro-scale hydrogel structures that move as temperature fluctuates. These novel active coatings will address a critical need for self-cleaning devices in healthcare applications, and could prevent bacterial contamination that leads to frequent infections and thousands of deaths annually in the United States. In addition, community outreach efforts will be designed that engage young students and will help to broaden the diversity of the technical workforce, and research internships will help prepare high school students for advanced studies in science and engineering. 

Smart, programmable materials that respond mechanically to environmental stimuli are needed for smart biomedical devices. Hydrogels with chromonic liquid crystalline order are of interest for such applications because they morph anisotropically in response to biologically-benign temperature changes, and because their actuation trajectory can be programmed by patterning the material's molecular alignment. A key challenge is to fabricate such complex actuators at length scales too small to access via 3D printing and in shape profiles that are not flat films. This award supports development of novel techniques for design and microfabrication of shape-morphing hydrogels, using hierarchical patterning of molecular orientation achieved by combining soft lithography and liquid crystal self-assembly. This fundamental research will test the hypothesis that the shape of soft lithography molds can be used to pattern molecular alignment in micro-scale structures made of chromonic liquid crystal hydrogels, and that these aligned hydrogels can undergo programmable actuation in response to biologically-benign temperature changes. This processing approach will be used to create artificial cilia-like structures. Experimental efforts will be closely coupled to theory/simulation at two levels. First, the molecular order (nematic director) arising from surface anchoring from the soft lithography mold and liquid crystal chirality will be modeled. Second, nonlinear finite element elastodynamics simulations will be used to model shape evolution of active hydrogel micro-devices with a given director field as they transform under stimulus. This collaborative project brings together a multidisciplinary team with complementary expertise in responsive materials chemistry, materials modeling, and mechanical design.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: National Science Foundation ENG Award #1662113

 

Collaborative Research: Microfabrication and Self-Assembly of Shape-Changing Hydrogels with Chromonic Liquid Crystalline Order

 

Performance Period: 09/01/2017 - 08/31/2021

 

Performing Organizations: University of Pittsburgh in collaboration with Kent State University and Texas A&M University.

Liquid crystalline elastomers (LCE) transform the orientational order of their constituent molecules in response to stimuli to generate mechanical work. Through judicious material design the actuation profiles of LCE are comparable to (or exceed) that generated by mammalian muscles. Advances in manufacturing processes enable fabrication of adaptive structures using LCE, where their molecular order is defined with highly refined spatial selectivity. By harnessing them in practical applications, a new motif for the design of soft manipulators and actuators emerges with functionalities that are inaccessible with conventional hard actuators or traditional electromechanical systems.

This project demonstrated the ability to encode the response of a polymeric freeform, where individual voxels of the materials direct the transduction of stimuli into mechanical adaptation. This was used to 3D print structures ranging from the micro to the macroscopic scales that actuate by harnessing stimuli such a heat and light. A key breakthrough that emerged from this research was the ability to access molecular order within micrometer-scale voxels, which are composed into macroscopic freeforms. This was integrated with the ability to arbitrarily modulate material composition during the printing of molecularly patterned/ordered assemblies. Complex structural morphing can be programmed within the material's microstructure, including in multiresponsive configurations that harness multiplexed stimuli for manipulation, shape morphing and motility.

This project also explored the thermal response of LCE as a function of composition. Structure-property relationships were studied to present a trade-space of mechanical responses to stimuli. The ability to architect composites of LCE with eutectic Ga-In alloys was used to fabricate actuators that can be electrically powered at low voltages (<5V) and modest (~100mA) currents. The LCE's robust and repeatable thermomechanical actuation was harnessed in topologically confined ribbons and in pixelated assemblies of biaxially actuating films. The role of boundary conditions, geometric dimensions and molecular patterning on thermomechanical shape selection were explored to access non-linear structural transformations.

The fabrication methods developed in this work built on a fundamental understanding of how molecular patterning in micrometer-scale voxels can be controlled through a combination of externally applied fields, surface patterning and the composition. The ability to print materials with 3-dimensionally voxelated molecular patterns holds implications beyond stimuli-responsive soft matter. Applications are envisioned for enabling new classes of optical devices and reconfigurable functional properties, where the responses architected devices enables new design spaces. These include active phase modulation devices, optically bandgapped structures and adaptive metastructures.

Printing multimaterial freeforms unlocks access to adaptive topologies in composites, where actuation in response to stimuli drives tunable properties (e.g., modulus and strength). One instantiation involved the use of jamming in high-contrast composites, where actuation of LCE powers reversible compaction of secondary (inert) phases. Thus, architected structures that stiffen or soften in response to remotely directed stimuli (e.g., heat or light) become possible with applications in defense, robotics, and biomedical sectors. This research program supported education at the graduate and the undergraduate levels, where students collaborated integrally to fabricate and characterize the materials and manufacturing platforms. Technological innovations from this effort have resulted in patent applications centered around 3D printing of LCE. This provided a multifaceted education environment to train the next generation of researchers and manufacturing engineers.


Last Modified: 01/16/2023
Modified by: M Ravi Shankar

Image
  • a) 3D printing system where LCE's molecular order is encoded with a magnetic field. b) Surface alignment defines the prior mesophase director. The magnetic field reorients this. c) Polarized optical microscopy (POM) of the layers are illustrated. Scale 1mm.
    Reprinted (adapted) with permission from: Voxelated Molecular Patterning in Three-Dimensional Freeforms. ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces. 11 (31) 28236 to 28245, 2019. Copyright 2019 American Chemical Society
